articles.headline: John Kasich Is Back in New Hampshire. It’s Not for the Foliage.
articles.snippet: On the itinerary for the Ohio governor and 2016 presidential hopeful: a diner visit, a Q. and A. at a college and criticism of President Trump amid speculation about a 2020 run.
articles.abstract: On the itinerary for the Ohio governor and 2016 presidential hopeful: a diner visit, a Q. and A. at a college and criticism of President Trump amid speculation about a 2020 run.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — John Kasich had been here before. This much he pointed out, twice, before anyone had a chance to wonder why he was back.

articles.headline: Britain Aims to Close Gender Pay Gap With Transparency and Shame
articles.snippet: By forcing companies to publicly air salary discrepancies between men and women, Britain hopes to narrow the pay gap.
articles.abstract: By forcing companies to publicly air salary discrepancies between men and women, Britain hopes to narrow the pay gap.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gender pay gaps detailed by British companies in recent months surprised almost no one — men are paid more than women, often by a wide margin, at the vast majority of businesses.

articles.headline: Witness in Mueller Inquiry Who Advises U.A.E. Ruler Also Has Ties to Russia
articles.snippet: The witness, George Nader, has a roster of international connections that helped him arrange several meetings that have drawn the attention of the special counsel.
articles.abstract: The witness, George Nader, has a roster of international connections that helped him arrange several meetings that have drawn the attention of the special counsel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A witness who is cooperating in the special counsel investigation, George Nader, has connections to both the Persian Gulf states and Russia and may have information that links two important strands of the inquiry together, interviews and records show.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, David D. Kirkpatrick, Ben Protess and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Massive United States-Saudi Infrastructure Fund Struggles to Get Going
articles.snippet: Last year, Blackstone announced a $40 billion infrastructure fund with a huge commitment from the Saudis. It hasn’t come together as planned.
articles.abstract: Last year, Blackstone announced a $40 billion infrastructure fund with a huge commitment from the Saudis. It hasn’t come together as planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, the private equity firm Blackstone announced that it was creating a $40 billion fund that would invest in infrastructure projects in the United States. The fund’s largest backer was the government of Saudi Arabia, which agreed to kick in half the cash.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Is Amazon Bad for the Postal Service? Or Its Savior?
articles.snippet: President Trump says Amazon costs the U.S.P.S. billions of dollars. But the available evidence is far less certain, and some of it suggests the opposite.
articles.abstract: President Trump says Amazon costs the U.S.P.S. billions of dollars. But the available evidence is far less certain, and some of it suggests the opposite.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Five times in the last week, President Trump has pointed his Twitter arrows at Amazon over what he insists is a bad deal for the United States Postal Service.

articles.headline: Sinclair’s Boss Responds to Criticism: ‘You Can’t Be Serious!’
articles.snippet: In the wake of scrutiny prompted by a viral video, the Sinclair Broadcast Group’s chairman, David Smith, said his stations were no different from network news outlets.
articles.abstract: In the wake of scrutiny prompted by a viral video, the Sinclair Broadcast Group’s chairman, David Smith, said his stations were no different from network news outlets.
articles.lead_paragraph: David D. Smith, the chairman of Sinclair Broadcast Group, says the media is getting his company all wrong.

articles.headline: In Sparing Consumers Tariff Burden, Trump Hit Manufacturing
articles.snippet: If the tariffs stand, along with China’s retaliatory moves, they could damage industries that have relied on a global supply chain for their recovery.
articles.abstract: If the tariffs stand, along with China’s retaliatory moves, they could damage industries that have relied on a global supply chain for their recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the escalating economic showdown between the United States and China, President Trump is trying to put American shoppers first. The administration did not place tariffs on necessities like shoes and clothes, and mostly spared smartphones from the 25 percent levy on Chinese goods announced this week.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: With Tesla in a Danger Zone, Can Model 3 Carry It to Safety?
articles.snippet: A test drive shows the allure of the company’s mass-market electric car and limitations of its Autopilot system.
articles.abstract: A test drive shows the allure of the company’s mass-market electric car and limitations of its Autopilot system.
articles.lead_paragraph: As I zipped up the West Side Highway the other day in a gleaming red Tesla Model 3, I found myself wondering: Are American drivers ready for Autopilot?
